docTitle.titlePart:
Development and characterization of a 280 cm
2 vanadium/oxygen fuel
cell

byline.docAuthor: Jens Noack * , Carsten Cremers, Domnik Bayer, Jens Tübke, Karsten Pinkwart

byline.affiliation: Applied Electrochemistry, Fraunhofer Institute for Chemical Technology,

front.note: h i g h l i g h t s
front.div:
A vanadium/oxygen fuel cell with an active area of 280 cm
2 has been developed and tested.
The cell uses 2 membranes to avoid side reactions on the platinum ORR catalyst.
The cell performance has been compared to a 50 cm
2 design and had nearly similar values.
In both cells, the performance was limited by slow oxygen reduction rate at room temperature.

front.div:
a b s t r a c t
A vanadium/oxygen fuel cell with an active area of 280 cm
2 has been developed. The cell consisted of two
membranes with two half-cells and an intermediate chamber. The maximum achieved power density
was 23 mW cm
À2 at 0.56 V with lambda air ¼ 3 and a 1.6 M V
2þ solution at room temperature. The
average discharge power density was 19.6 mW cm
À2 at a constant current density of 40 mA cm
À2 with an
average voltage efficiency of 33%. The fuel based energy density was 18.2% of the theoretical value with
11.8 Wh L
À1
. In comparison with a similarly constructed 50 cm
2 cell, both achieved similar performance
levels. An analysis using the half-cell potential profiles and by means of impedance spectroscopy
revealed that, as for the 50 cm
2 cell, the low rate of oxygen reduction reaction significantly affected the
performance of the cell. Thus gives potential for the optimization of the cathode reaction and a reduction
in the ohmic resistances potential for higher power densities.
